This guy is a millionaire real estate developer in Florida that has pushed for centrist to conservative Democrats for decades, including donating to Marco Rubio and doing some really [shady](https://inthesetimes.com/article/dnc-finance-chair-democratic-party-bernie-sanders-chris-korge) real estate shit in Florida. Comment: >So do you want the DNC to be impartial or not?  The DNC, under Debbie's chairpersonship wasn't impartial though, it wasn't a "whiff of impropriety" as you put it; it was pretty blatantly partisan for Clinton. There were fewer primary debates in the 2016 DNC primary season (only 6 debates). Whereas the previous election in which there was no Democratic presidential incumbent, 2008, there were *26* primary debates.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Democratic_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums?wprov=sfla1  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Democratic_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums?wprov=sfla1  *20 fewer debates*. That meant that other candidates like O'Malley and Sanders had way fewer opportunities to appeal to delegates and voters, and worked in Clinton's advantage.  And the damage was already done by the time Debbie stepped down, so it was mission accomplished for Clinton, which she ended up losing to trump anyway.   I think people are fucking sick of establishment Dems who, above all else, seem to value seniority over effectiveness and working class ideals. If that means transformation of the DNC from the inside out, I for one would welcome it.

Comment: Stop lying.  >Individuals who had maxed out their $2,700 contribution limit to the campaign could write an additional check for $353,400 to the Hillary Victory Fund—that figure represented $10,000 to each of the 32 states’ parties who were part of the Victory Fund agreement—$320,000—and $33,400 to the DNC. The money would be deposited in the states first, and transferred to the DNC shortly after that. Money in the battleground states usually stayed in that state, but all the other states funneled that money directly to the DNC, which quickly transferred the money to Brooklyn.  >“Wait,” I said. “That victory fund was supposed to be for whoever was the nominee, and the state party races. You’re telling me that Hillary has been controlling it since before she got the nomination?”  >Gary said the campaign had to do it or the party would collapse.  >“That was the deal that Robby struck with Debbie,” he explained, referring to campaign manager Robby Mook. “It was to sustain the DNC. We sent the party nearly $20 million from September until the convention, and more to prepare for the election.”  >**Right around the time of the convention**, the leaked emails revealed Hillary’s campaign was grabbing money from the state parties for its own purposes, leaving the states with very little to support down-ballot races. A [Politico story published on May 2, 2016](https://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/clinton-fundraising-leaves-little-for-state-parties-222670), described the big fund-raising vehicle she had launched through the states the summer before, quoting a vow she had made to rebuild “the party from the ground up … when our state parties are strong, we win. That’s what will happen.”  >Yet the states kept less than half of 1 percent of the $82 million they had amassed from the extravagant fund-raisers Hillary’s campaign was holding, just as Gary had described to me when he and I talked in August. When the Politico story described this arrangement as “essentially … money laundering” for the Clinton campaign, Hillary’s people were outraged at being accused of doing something shady.  Hillary's campaign looted the victory fund, leaving little money for down ballot races and used it to end run around donor limits.  Your continued denials and deflections fool nobody who actually clicked the link.  Yes, I am aware she had said, when asked it was 'fair'.  What else was she going to say?  My party is nakedly corrupt?  My party considers our primaries a formality and a nuisance to running the candidate we've anointed?  No, of course not, that would be both stupid and suicidal.  Instead, when faced with literal fucking Nazis she agreed to circle the wagons, encouraged Bernie to do the same (which he did), and then did what she could to protect the party.  In her own words, in describing how she was going to handle this:  >  >“Hello, senator. I’ve completed my review of the DNC and I did find the cancer,” I said. “But I will not kill the patient.”

Comment: >And that didn’t take money away from Sanders. Nor was it the money used in the primary against him.  >It also wasn’t the DNC funding him. The section you quoted clearly shows it was donations that Clinton was bringing in.  Nobody said she took money from Sanders, this is a straw man and an intentional misrepresentation of the issue.  People said she took money from the DNC separate and above what her campaign actually raised in order to pay for her campaign.  This she very much did do.  When one campaign is allowed to use party funds for their campaign but their competitors aren't, that is unethical and that lack of ethics came from DWS and the DNC leadership making an agreement with the Hillary campaign.  There were two sections quoted, one about how Hillary used her position as controller of the party finances to let her collect more donations than the rules allowed her to.  The second was about how she used her control over DNC finances to take money from funding donated to and set aside for down ballot races.  Both of these things can be, and are, true simultaneously.  Your deflection and misrepresentation is a failure.  >In other words, when she supports your position you believe her, and when she doesn’t, she’s obviously lying. Give me a break.  Oh look, more dishonesty.  She did exactly what she said she was going to do - do an honest inquiry into the corruption in the DNC, and then help her party win. Then, in the second reply, I said "No, I don't believe openly stating 'we intend to put some money aside to give a chance for fresh blood to ascend in the party in places where politicians in our party aren't doing what we need them to do right now', being completely transparent about this fact, is the equivalent of what Donna Bazile reported she found after she took over the DNC chair where, for example, the entire fundraising apparatus of the DNC was turned over to the Hillary campaign without the knowledge of the public or other candidates. Conflating the two is obviously dishonest."  So, no, despite you lying about it, I did in fact address that red herring written in the form of the 'have you stopped beating your wife' dishonest question framing which uses the implication of something false to force the answerer into agreeing to a falsehood.
